Article.ArticleTitle: Prospective longitudinal evaluation of hospitalised COVID-19 survivors 3 and 12 months after discharge.

Abstract.AbstractText: Long-term outcome data of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) survivors are needed to understand their recovery trajectory and additional care needs.

A prospective observational multicentre cohort study was carried out of adults hospitalised with COVID-19 from March through May 2020. Workup at 3 and 12 months following admission consisted of clinical review, pulmonary function testing, 6-min walk distance (6MWD), muscle strength, chest computed tomography (CT) and quality of life questionnaires. We evaluated factors correlating with recovery by linear mixed effects modelling.

Of 695 patients admitted, 299 and 226 returned at 3 and 12 months, respectively (median age 59 years, 69% male, 31% severe disease). About half and a third of the patients reported fatigue, dyspnoea and/or cognitive impairment at 3 and 12 months, respectively. Reduced 6MWD and quadriceps strength were present in 20% and 60% at 3 months versus 7% and 30% at 12 months. A high anxiety score and body mass index correlated with poor functional recovery. At 3 months, diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (D LCO) and total lung capacity were below the lower limit of normal in 35% and 18%, decreasing to 21% and 16% at 12 months; predictors of poor D LCO recovery were female sex, pre-existing lung disease, smoking and disease severity. Chest CT improved over time; 10% presented non-progressive fibrotic changes at 1 year.

Many COVID-19 survivors, especially those with severe disease, experienced limitations at 3 months. At 1 year, the majority showed improvement to almost complete recovery. To identify additional care or rehabilitation needs, we recommend a timely multidisciplinary follow-up visit following COVID-19 admission.

MedlineCitation.CoiStatement: Conflict of interest: Y. Vande Weygaerde declares consulting fees from KCE: Federaal Kenniscentrum voor de Gezondheidszorg for participating on a panel for evaluation of interventional studies concerning treatment of patients with long COVID; payment from Wetenschappelijke Vereniging voor Verzekeringsgeneeskunde for a presentation about post-COVID syndrome; and support for attending meetings and/or travel from Insmed and Chiesi, all in the 36 months prior to manuscript submission. I. Gyselinck declares PhD grant funding from Research Foundation Flanders, in the 36 months prior to manuscript submission. C. Bosteels declares FWO funding as a PhD student; payment or honoraria for the Basic Science GSK Award in Pulmonology 2020, AstraZeneca Award 2021 and Romain Pauwels Award 2021; and support paid to their institution for the Keystone Symposia Scholarship 2019 and the European Federation of Immunological Societies–European Journal of Immunology Travel Grant, all in the 36 months prior to manuscript submission. B.N. Lambrecht declares VIB grants M901 BaLa COVID-19 SARPAC trial and M902 BaLa COVID-19 COVAID trial, in the 36 months prior to manuscript submission. S. Everaerts declares payment or honoraria from GlaxoSmithKline and Boehringer Ingelheim; payment for expert testimony from Chiesi; support for attending meetings and/or travel from GlaxoSmithKline, Chiesi and Teva; and participation on a Data Safety Monitoring Board or Advisory Board for Chiesi, all in the 36 months prior to manuscript submission. L. Godinas declares grants and consulting fees from Merck Sharp & Dohme, Biotest and Johnson & Johnson, in the 36 months prior to manuscript submission. R. Gosselink declares royalties of less than EUR 500 from Springer Verlag, in the 36 months prior to manuscript submission. W. Janssens declares support for the present manuscript from KU Leuven/UZ Leuven COVID research funds. E. Van Braeckel declares funding for the present manuscript from the Ghent University Special Research Fund for COVID-19 Research (BOFCOV2020000801); as well as that, they hold a tenure-track position at Ghent University supported by the Special Research Fund (BOF-ZAP); and that they are Principal Investigator in a trial sponsored by Exevir Bio and sub-investigator in the ZILU-COV trial sponsored by UCB and the COV-AID and SARPAC trials sponsored by the Belgian Health Care Knowledge Centre (KCE); and, within the 36 months prior to manuscript submission, consulting fees paid to their institution by GlaxoSmithKline and Merck Sharp & Dohme, payment or honoraria to their institution from Gilead and GlaxoSmithKline and payment to their institution for participation on a data safety monitoring board or advisory board from Merck Sharp & Dohme; and that they hold the unpaid roles of Chair of the Belgian Respiratory Society working group on respiratory infections, member of the Belgian COVID-19 guidelines group and that they provide unpaid COVID-19-related expert advice to Belgian government agencies. All other authors declare no competing interests.
